ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed appreciation for Deaf culture and ASL as a language. I also developed my hand-eye coordination and confidence with communication.
I developed basic conversation comprehension and acquired a lot of new, relevant vocabulary
I developed basic communication, story telling, respect and culture of the ASL, BASL, and many participating communities.
Knowledge about Deaf culture and connections with the community
Understand of and communication of basic sentences

I learned the ASL alphabet, how to ask simple questions and communicate basic ideas, and some conversational vocabulary. Through homework, class presentations, and events for the asynchronous hours, I also learned about the Deaf community in the United States, Deaf history and storytelling, and some elements of Deaf culture.

During the course, I developed a very strong foundation in ASL, especially for an introductory course. Beyond advancing my signing aptitude, I learned more about deaf culture and had many opportunities to work on applying my skills outside the classroom. I also gained valuable experiences interacting with my classmates and other individuals, which proved very insightful.
I learned basic understanding of ASL and about deaf culture.
I gained an introduction to ASL and also the history and parameters of Deaf culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: curriculum is straightforward. many opportunities to practice and improve. class is low-stress but high-reward. it really transformed my perception of ASL and the Deaf community. 
Weaknesses: rarely receive feedback from professor and assignments go ungraded for entire semester.
Zen is an amazing professor who is extremely engaged with his students.

strengths--interesting content, work, meaningful discussions about the Deaf community
weaknesses--a lot of the content on quizzes are not taught in class, so you have to just guess. also this year (fall 2022) there isn't a service project for ASL1 but a lot of the canvas assignments weren't changed yet. There were a lot of journal entries about the service project and I wasn't sure what to put for them, so I didn't put much, and the professor marked me down pretty substantially. I think the grading is the most stressful part, as grades were put in at the last second and there were a lot of modules in Signing Naturally that just failed to sync with canvas and either showed up as late or missing.
Fun class! Would be nice to have more feedback to know how we're doing

The homework and classes make the proper way to sign and certain appropriate variations for some words pretty clear. The "asynchronous hours" component is wonderful and provides great opportunities for practicing the language and learning more about the Deaf/Hard of Hearing community. However, it would be much improved if there were a list of all events that qualify at the beginning of the semester. Without it, it is hard to plan ahead and determine how best to complete the required number of hours. As it is, it is best to aim to complete them earlier in the semester or during times with less of a workload.

Many of the strengths include strong engagement from Zen (he was a very fun and competent professor), well paced (in terms of content), and a great atmosphere in the classroom. In terms of future improvements, Id like to learn more nuance vocabulary for conversations.
Amazing, the class was so fun and I looked forward to going. Concepts were taught at the right pace and the content flowed nicely.
The course was well organized to introduce new vocab, though at times class itself felt repetitive and assignments did not seem to accord with what was being done in class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, I would.
Absolutely! ASL is very fun and a different style of learning than most other courses at Yale.
Yes! ASL is such a great language to learn and it really feels unique. I really recommend getting involved with the program at some point in your Yale career as it's quite special to Yale.
YES! It is such a fun class and you learn a ton!

I would absolutely recommend this course! American Sign Language is different from spoken language in some ways, which is fascinating for those interested in linguistics. In addition, it makes you consider accessibility and your own role in making the world more inclusive.
Yes, Zen is an excellent professor and made the class super enjoyable!
Yes, ASL is amazing and it really opens your eyes to a different culture and community.
I think every student should learn ASL.
